title-group.article-title: Should the World Health Organization’s Definition of Predominant Breastfeeding Include Fruit Juice?

body.p: In 1991 the World Health Organization (WHO) and United Nations Children’s Fund introduced standardized definitions for assessing breastfeeding practices.1 Concerning breastfeeding categories, a modification was made in 2007 to the definition of exclusive breastfeeding to permit inclusion of oral rehydration salts that are widely used to prevent and treat dehydration.2,3 The definition of predominant breastfeeding, a practice that takes place mostly during the first 6 months of life, has remained basically unchanged1-3 and still allows the infant to receive fruit juice (Table 1).

body.p: The WHO definition of predominant breastfeeding needs to be updated as it seems inappropriate for infants to consume fruit juice before 6 months of age and before the introduction of solid, semisolid, or soft foods.4,5 About 10 years ago, the American Academy of Pediatrics’ Committee on Nutrition discussed the early use of fruit juice during the first months of life and concluded: “Fruit juice offers no nutritional benefit for infants younger than 6 months.”5 This Committee recommended that “juice should not be introduced into the diet of infants before 6 months of age,”5 which is consistent with the WHO view that breast milk “provides all the energy and nutrients that the infant needs for the first months of life.”6 Offering fruit juice to the predominantly breastfed infant could introduce the risk of having juice replace breast milk in the diet5 and result in detrimental effects.7 By allowing the predominantly breastfed infant to receive juice during the first months of life and before the introduction of solid, semisolid, or soft foods, the WHO offers suboptimal guidance for pediatricians, caregivers, and mothers, pointing them toward a potentially misleading feeding practice with possible unsafe effects for the infant.

On the whole, one can therefore conclude that the WHO and the international scientific community should discuss the possibility of no longer including fruit juice among the liquids that an infant is allowed to receive under the predominant breastfeeding category. This matter should be considered to benefit the future generations of infants.
